title: AI Slop Is Breaking the Internet as We Know It (Live at SXSW 2025)

rawLines.text: [Music]
Okay. Uh, thank you everyone for coming.
Uh, I'm Jason Kevler. I'm a co-founder
of 404 Media.
Woo. Uh, it means a lot to us that
you're here. We're first going to talk
to you about uh, AI Slop and then
afterward we're going to talk a little
bit more about 404 media. Um, I know
some of you are here to hang out with
other people, which is very good. Um,
but if you could be like further back if
you're going to talk to other people,
that would be helpful. Thank you. Yeah.
Uh, so I'm here with Sam Cole. Hello,
Sam. Hi. Thanks, guys. I'm a co-founder
of For Media Azo. Um, yeah, we're really
excited to be here obviously. Um, it's
so cool to see you all. Uh, yeah, we're
going to get into some some weird stuff
this afternoon. So, I'm excited. And
this is Brian Merchant. And I'll let
Brian introduce himself. Yeah. honorary
404 uh adjacent
human and uh yeah, fellow uh fellow
traveler in uh the tech journalism uh
world. I used to work with these two
back in the motherboard days. We all
worked at Motherboard Advice for for a
stint before that ship went down in
flames dramatically. Um and yeah,
couldn't be more pleased to be here with
these uh heroes of modern journalism
here. Let's give them another round of
applause. It's 404 media stuff they've
done with independent tech journalism is
just it's astounding. We need it and
it's the best. So this panel is going to
be 45 minutes of Brian saying nice
things to us.
So I've been very obsessed with
artificial intelligence and AI slop on
social media. So uh I'm going to take
you through a couple slides very quickly
uh just to give a a lay of the land. Uh,
I have this thesis that AI slop is
essentially a brute force attack against
the algorithms that control the nature
of our reality, which sounds very lofty,
but I think is actually what is
happening. Um, I've been writing about
AI slop for about 18 months. Uh, sort of
started with shrimp Jesus and uh, you
know, AI generated images that were
going very very viral on Facebook. Uh,
but it's not just Facebook, it's
Instagram, it's Tik Tok, it's YouTube,
and there's an entire uh like content
creation factory apparatus around all of
this, which we'll definitely talk about.
Uh, so I'm going to flip through just
like a few things that I've seen over
the last uh few years very quickly. So,
these are like dozens of images of Jesus
uh being made out of Coke bottles uh
with poor children. Uh we have some uh
Jesus and pot flight attendants over
here. Um and this is an Indian YouTuber
who teaches people how to make AI spam
to put on Facebook. And so after like
months of writing about this sort of
thing, uh I became obsessed with
figuring out where it came from. And it
turns out that all of these uh like
bizarre AI images are being monetized
directly through Facebook itself through
the Facebook creators program which
gives a fraction of ad revenue uh
depending on how viral an image goes.
And so there's like all these side
hustle bros in India, Vietnam, the
Philippines, some in the United States
as well who teach people how to create
uh AI slop and spam it to Facebook.
Um, see this uh and then there's this
guy here who has become very famous on
YouTube because he made this image which
is very small but uh it's an image of a
train that is made out of leaves and he
was paid
$431 uh for this image because it went
mega viral on Facebook and now he's been
on like 20 different podcasts talking
about how he did it. So there's like
thousands and thousands of people all
over the world who are just making stuff
to put on the internet um in hopes that
it goes viral. Uh at first it was just
like images of Jesus and uh like bizarre
trains made out of grass and then
Hurricane Helen happened and this image
went extremely viral. Uh it is not real.
And here's the head of the Republican
National Committee saying that they
don't care if the image is real or not
because the vibe uh is such that it
seems true. And then if you scroll
Facebook right now, you'll see tens of
thousands of different images and videos
of Elon Musk, um like inspiration porn,
I would call it, where Elon Musk has
invented a UFO or a $10,000 micro house.
Um, and a lot of these images have, you
know, 10, 15 likes, and then others will
have like 7 million likes and like
hundreds of thousands of comments and
things like that. And clearly, very many
people can't tell that it's real or
fake. Uh, this has expanded beyond
Facebook, of course. It's expanded into
libraries. It's expanded into Tik Tok.
It's expanded into SEO, spam, things
like that.
Um, here are some AI generated books
that you can take out from the public
library, including AI
monization of your faceless YouTube
channel.
Um,
and I say that this strategy is brute
force because uh they're essentially in
my opinion looking for weaknesses in the
algorithm and when they find something
that works you create a lot of that. And
so there's multiple influencers who are
teaching people how to do this. Uh they
have, you know, Slack courses and
Discord channels where you can pay them
$50 a month to learn how to do this. And
this one is from a guy named Daniel
Bittton. Uh he emails me every single
day automatically. Um and he likens
making like going viral on YouTube
shorts to u being a serial killer. Uh
because there's a pattern to the
algorithm. I think the important thing
to look at here though is now AI does
95% of the work and ready to start
feeding the algorithm what it's actually
hungry for. Um, this is another email
from a guy named Musa who flies in a
private jet. He is 17 years old. I don't
know if he owns the private jet or not,
but he says that he's gotten rich by
spamming uh these platforms. And
similarly, he's just saying let the
algorithm do its thing.
Uh, and now I'm going to show you what
my Instagram feed looks like very
quickly, and then I'll bring in Brian
and
Sam. Some of these are gross. I'll just
preface, but I think you can probably
handle
it. We have Jesus fighting the Grim
Reaper. Here we
have whatever this is.
This is totally unedited, by the way.
This is like when I open Instagram and I
scroll through reals. This is this is
what I'm getting. Um, we have this
horrible title wave that killed all
these
people.
Um, things like that. Uh, we also have a
lot of wildfire content. Uh, we'll start
with this, but there's a lot of LA
wildfire disinformation
here. This has 39,000 likes. If you
can't see,
um, there's a lot of uh how to build the
pyramids as well. like this. This is how
the pyramids were built in ancient Egypt
with a gigantic
man. Some mermaid content. Um so on and
so forth. And the last thing I'll show
you is uh AI influencers are very uh
popular on Instagram now. Um we have
this with 519,000 likes. Whatever it is
going on
here, we have this woman with three
breasts. Uh she's pretty popular on
Instagram as
well. And I guess we'll just start
there. What What do you guys uh what do
you guys think? You like So anyway, what
do you think? Yeah.
No, but uh thank you guys for staying.
Yeah, thank you for staying. Thank you
for not running away in horror. You're
very brave. Yeah, they're sweating. I
can tell. But it's fine. But Sam, you've
written a lot about AI slop as well and
how it can uh be dangerous. uh you know,
field guides to eating mushrooms. Yeah.
Generated by AI, things like this. Yeah.
I mean, I feel like it's really funny to
look at the slop. Um first of all, I
love that slop is the term for this. I
think maybe Jason coined that. Someone
coined it. Possibly you.
Probably someone here. Possibly. I don't
know. Um but yeah, I mean the the AI
slop stuff is really funny, but it's
also I mean we're looking at this as
journalists obviously, so we're like why
is this happening? like what is the kind
of the um the ecosystem the perverse
economy that's behind this um and so
there's the visual examples but then
there's also LLM and AI slop of like a
textbased form so um we had when we
first started for four one of our first
stories is about uh AI generated books
on Amazon for mushroom foraging which is
obviously a very niche hobby that can
get you in a lot of trouble if you do it
wrong um it's uh something that the New
York Micological Society had flagged um
as being life or death essentially. It's
you know if you if you eat the wrong
mushroom in the wild uh it could be
really serious and these books were
saying you know like it's no problem
just cook it and eat it. It's like this
no human is involved in the expertise
that into this book. Um, but obviously
that those books sell and you know
people buy them and um Amazon makes
money and the sellers make money and I
think we're going to get into a little
bit about why these make money and how
these kind of images make money. But um
yeah, I mean it's it's scary in a way
that is so absurd you have to laugh. But
you know it's um Brian, you write a lot
about um AI empowered automation, but
have you thought about all the jobs that
AI slop is creating for teenagers
who quick on Instagram? Will anyone
think of the teenage content farmers
spamming AI content uh slop algorithms?
Yes. No. I mean, I think that is a
really good point. Um, and that it's
easy to scoff at this stuff. It's e easy
to write it off. But just like Sam was
talking about, if even a few of these
guides to consuming, you know, mushrooms
or foraging for mushrooms make it into
the public hands and they don't
understand what it is properly that it
that it was created by these algorithms,
it can be very dangerous. Um and on
those edge cases uh it is having sort of
outsized effects on the broader economy
right like so by flooding uh especially
creative uh adjacent or creative fields
properly with all of this AI uh slop
both image and text it is slowly eroding
the market for this stuff and you know
it's not really anything new uh this is
a process that that began you could
argue um back when people started you
know blogging or aggregating, you know,
uh, internet content, um, and and sort
of capturing some of the value that was
put forward by reporters or writers or,
uh, people sharing images online. Um,
but by able by being able to spam this,
uh, out at such great sort of scale and
at such uh, e with such ease. Right now,
it's very cheap. It's very easy to do
this. Uh, we can't really take for
granted some of the potential long-term
impacts of this. So my I wrote a book
called Blood in the Machine. It's also
the name of my newsletter that I kind of
document a lot of this stuff going on
now. And you can draw a lot of parallels
to what's happening with sort of
creative labor now back with what
happened to the artisan workers, the
cloth workers in the industrial
revolution where these sort of
technologies of mass production and
automation enabled the uh the cheap
production of goods, the um uh sheuing
of the of the skilled worker. Um, so
there's quite a few parallels and the
stuff doesn't need to be good, right? It
just has to be good enough a lot of
times. So there are different categories
of slop. The stuff that um Jason just
showed us, u, I'm glad I didn't have to
watch that
again. It's some of it's pretty pretty
grotesque. Um, but then there's the
stuff that you probably see more of
that's just slowly being substituted for
other uh, you know, other purpose. Maybe
it's on somebody's newsletter, a
Substack. Maybe it's being uh used on
social media. Maybe it's making its way
into like a corporate presentation. But
so I think we have to both recognize
that this stuff is ridiculous and I
think most people uh are object to its
artistic quality most of the time, but
it can still have uh real impacts as it
does sort of gain steam. Yeah, I think
that's the the biggest thing I want
y'all to understand is that as I've been
writing about this, a lot of people say,
"Do people really think that this is
real? Are the people in engaging with it
real? And I spent a long time scrolling
through Facebook comments and trying to
determine whether the people commenting
on these things were real or whether
they were bots themselves, whether there
was some sort of like engagement
mechanism here that made these things go
viral, but there there wasn't really
that many human beings in the loop
looking at it. And I've come to the
conclusion that it it's a mix. I mean
there's definitely some automation
happening here where you know maybe
there's a thousand likes at the
beginning that gets it going in the
algorithm but I think that the target of
this AI slop is not other human beings
that you know the people who make it say
exactly that it's the audience is not
human beings the audience is the
algorithm itself and the audience is
figuring out how to game the algorithm
so that it does show up in the feeds of
human beings and if something is shown
to a 100 million people and a few of
them like it and comment on it like that
is enough and I think what we from what
we know about Instagram algorithm you
know the Facebook algorithm it's like
opening up a a real and seeing a man
turn into a spider in the first three
frames of the the clip will make you
stay on that because you might say hey
what the [ __ ] is this and that's a
signal to the algorithm that this is
interesting content And I think that as
writers, and you know, we're not
artists, but we work with a lot of
artists, it's like we we do have to
think sometimes about, you know, will
this perform well on social media? Will
this perform well in the algorithm? And
let's say I spend a week working on a
story that I report very deeply and and
put out there and, you know, it doesn't
get much engagement. It doesn't perform
well in the algorithm. Well, you know,
you you have these people making a
thousand images in three minutes and
they're able to iterate on that
instantly. And so it has the effect of
not just flooding out human content, but
also they're able to A B CDE E test all
of this stuff. And then when something
is working, they can just spam more and
more and more of that and, you know,
collect the fractions of a scent. Yeah.
And importantly, right, the platforms
don't care or they're happy to have this
happen because it's it's it's more
content and more more engagement when it
does fire off, right? Like, so there's
Facebook doesn't really care if the if
the content that's going on to it is AI
generated or human generated. In fact,
it might preference the the latter. So,
I mean, I'm I'm curious because you guys
have reported on this a bunch. Um, and
when you first did, I I honestly, bless
my naive uh soul, I thought that, you
know, Facebook would respond to the
outrage by sort of clamping down on it,
but had that hasn't happened really at
all. No, not at all. In fact, Facebook
has tried to create its own uh, you
know, AI agents. They've talked about
allowing you users to create AI
profiles. Mark Zuckerberg has talked
about this future where, you know, you
might have your own Facebook profile,
but then you'll have seven others that
are your AI avatars that are out there
spamming Facebook for you. And
um it's it's interesting because people
ask me like what is the endgame of this?
Like why is Facebook doing this? And I
think from what we know about Facebook,
and I always say Facebook because that's
where it's worst, but the other
platforms are are the same more or less.
They're all filled with this stuff. uh
we know that they are trying to
advertise to people in as specific a way
as possible. They are trying to create
you know psychographic profiles of you,
get your demographic information and
then provide you the most optimized
advertisement to you. And I think what
they are hoping is
that AI content will be able to provide
you extraordinarily specific content
that is tailored to what Facebook thinks
you are. And so I don't know if that's
like weird crabs turning into Jesus uh
and you're really into that, there will
be a never-ending feed of AI generated
crab Jesuses that you can scroll through
and they they can target ads to you
based on that. Uh the other thing that I
wanted to say about how Facebook enables
this and is profiting off of it is that
uh you know they're an advertising
business and for a long time you used to
be able to make several ads on Facebook.
So, if you were a brand, you could make
like three or four different versions of
an ad and you could test different
messages, you could put uh and then you
could put money behind the one that is
performing the best. And very recently,
they announced this program called
Advantage Plus where instead of making
two or three ads and AB testing
different messages to different
audiences, you know, maybe the the call
to action is slightly different on one,
maybe the uh you know, image is slightly
different on another. You can now do
this with AI, generative AI, and you can
make a thousand ads and target it to a
thousand different segments and only put
money behind the ones that are
performing. And so when I talk about
like a brute force attack on reality,
it's like it's not just the people who
are spamming Facebook, it's that the
companies themselves are making and
enabling these tools for uh you know,
advertisers to just hit you over the
head with this stuff constantly. Uh, and
I I don't think that's good personally.
Yeah. I mean, I guess something I we've
talked about um in private, but I would
love to kind of work through it here,
too, is why this is bad for everyone.
It's like if you don't care about AI and
you think, oh, well, the the stuff is
whatever. um or if you're like AI is
good in certain use cases, which I think
we've also, you know, we've kind of gone
back and forth on that, but like why
does this kind of trash the whole
economy of creativity
um at scale? I guess if you're working
toward an algorithm and appeasing the
algorithm and being uh getting
engagement for an algorithm, how does
that affect everyone? Um and I know
Brian's written quite a bit about this.
um you know it's like it's not just oh
this stuff is ugly to look at. It's
actually affecting like how we use these
platforms and the way that we're
contributing to them. Yeah. I mean it is
and it does really seem like I mean
there's a couple and there's a couple
caveats too and I'd be we can we could
talk about in a second too because you
know I think one of the things that's
enabling this right now is the fact that
like the cost of of of running like an
AI generated uh search or or producing
an image um you know the like sort of
like the compute costs and the and the
energy costs of doing that right now
aren't really priced into a lot of
models or if they are it's if it's
something if it is like
um a model that's being run by a big
tech company, then you know they have
such a huge um war chest of of capital
that they can do that for a long time.
But an interesting question is like is
eventually you know if if if those costs
are are are factored in. Um does it m it
makes sense anymore to continue to do
this to sort of if you have to if you
have to pay to generate images even um
you know just a a small threshold more
then does that sort of ruin sort of the
the slop economy for those worst
offenders that are spamming it out
there? Uh I'd be curious to hear what
Yeah, I mean right now the all of the
guides to doing this because there's
always a guide. There's always like a a
guy at the top of the pyramid, if you
will, uh who is teaching the people
underneath uh how to do this and for a
small fee, you can purchase their
prompts and their their tips and things
like that. Um almost everyone is using
free tools at the moment. And by free, I
mean free trials of generative AI tools
or things like being image creator,
which is free. And when you run out of
generations on the free account, you can
just make another account and have seven
different accounts and do that. And so
it it's kind of the uh Mark Andre Uber
effect where uh you know Uber was cheap
for a very long time because it was
being subsidized by the venture
capitalists that were investing in it.
And that's the period that we're in with
artificial intelligence right now where
the people investing in and building
this technology are taking a huge loss
on this stuff. Um, and presumably they
don't want to do that forever. So there
may there may come a day when it's not
uh profitable to do this. I think the
big question for me is like whether
social media will be completely
destroyed before that happens. And what
I just showed you where I was scrolling
my feed and that that's what I'm seeing.
I don't think that's most people's
experiences at this very moment. I think
that I've given enough signals that as a
journalist who writes about this like
show me the weird AI stuff that that's
what I've told the algorithm that I
want. But as you saw like a lot of these
um videos have hundreds of thousands
millions of likes. And so that is
starting to happen on Instagram and
Facebook at scale where people's feeds
are being taken over by this stuff. And
I wonder when the collapse point comes
where it is so hard to find other human
generated content that you know these
social media platforms are just all AI
like more or less and it's happening on
search as well. I mean so Google is
being flooded and of course Google
itself is you know putting AI overviews
at the top of things too but the entire
SEO industry is is AI focused at this
point too. And I mean it's just a
reflection of the problem when you have
just like so such highly monopolized
uh sort of tech infrastructures and
platforms that we we rely on that maybe
Facebook would be more responsive to
sort of the abuse of uh of of being
flooded by AI images for uh a little bit
of profit for some content farmers. um
maybe Google would be more receptive to
improving its product and not serving
us, you know, results that are going to
tell you to eat poisonous mushrooms or
whatever if, you know, there if there
were more viable uh alternatives or or
an ecosystem in which they didn't
dominate 90% of the market share. Um and
I do think that like I do I do really
ultimately think this is a really toxic
thing. Um I I cuz I kind of see as I you
you call it brute forcing which I like.
I also think about sort of AI slop
almost as kind of like the like the
shock troops, right? They're just kind
of like these are the most egregious
examples of of sort of AI generated
stuff and then it kind of moves the
Overton window and makes other AI
generative generated stuff seem a little
bit more reasonable by comparison. Um
here's a fun and topical example. So I I
I was the tech columnist at the LA Times
until last year um when I was part of
the mass layoffs uh along with like 120
of my my colleagues. Um, and then at the
end of that year, uh, the owner, uh,
Patrick Sunong, who has not managed to
keep himself out of the news much these
days, uh, for a number of reasons, but
he announced a new, uh, a new feature
called called AI insights, and it's a
new feature that's part that's on a on
an opinion piece, or they call them
voices now, but if somebody writes an
opinion piece, now it it features an AI
that will determine or attempt to
determine the political content or
positioning of this piece. So, you know,
it'll say like this is a moderate
liberal piece or something like that.
And then it will take the initiative uh
to offer some some uh you know, some
counter examples and some uh yeah, buts,
right? Some both sidesing, which is uh
what all journalists love is uh when
they have to both sides their their
argument. Um, anyways, this thing
recently got in trouble for uh somebody
wrote a column, one of my former
colleagues wrote a column saying uh my
hometown my hometown of Anaheim uh you
know has this checkered past because at
one point the city council was dominated
by the KKK and we need to remember this
this sorted history uh so that it
doesn't happen again. And of course the
a the AI bot comes out and says, "Well,
maybe the KKK wasn't that bad. Maybe it
had some points. Uh some people have
said it wasn't a totally hatedriven move
uh movement. Uh and obviously this
caused some backlash. They had to get
rid of the AI thing for now at least on
that article. But this is just an
example. Like here's a here's some AI
generated content that is be that is I
think we could call it slop. It's
garbage. It's nobody really wants it.
And yet the management of a company is
trying to use it to sort of create more
value. I kind in my last newsletter I
kind of being cheeky said this they've
replaced me with an AI that defends the
KKK but it's not quite that onetoone but
you can look at the value propositions
here what the tech companies are trying
to do to sort of uh plug the gap or to
see how what they can get away with by
generating content as cheaply as
possible or getting people to engage
with content as cheaply as possible. Um
and it's not just big tech, right? We've
seen this at Sports Illustrated using AI
slop. We've seen it at uh at at some
portions of USA Today and CNN, the old
tech company. So, it is like creeping up
BuzzFeed. Buzzfeed fired all of its
reporters and then said, "We're going to
try uh making some AI quizzes uh
instead." Uh again, so it's just this
rise of this force that is, you know, I
I do think that it has this destructive
capacity that that needs to be
recognized. Yeah. I I think that um so
Sam was the first person who ever wrote
about deep fakes um ever which and she
totally owned that story uh you know
2018 something like this many years ago
and when deep fakes came out like face
swapping technology Sam was reporting on
how it was being used uh to make
non-consentual pornography of
celebrities and women and you know
essentially do sex crimes to people And
the immediate response from like
politicians was one
of this is going to be really bad for
national security because what if
someone makes Donald Trump saying that
there's going to be launch a nuke or
something? And so I want to ask Sam
because I think to to Brian's point
there are
there's the intended use of this stuff
which is like use it to make yourself
more efficient, use it to make your
workers more efficient, so on and so
forth. But it's like every time one of
these things gets released, there's like
the quote unquote
utopian productive uses of this thing,
which we could argue about adnauseium
anyway. And then there's the way that
people are actually using this. And to
this day, the dominant use of artificial
intelligence is to make porn of
non-conentual porn of women. And Sam has
done amazing reporting on that and just
wanted to hear more. Yeah. Yeah. I mean,
I don't know if it's I feel like that
deep fakes are not quite in this in the
slop bucket, but slap is kind of a out
like an outcropping of the deep fake
phenomenon. Um, yeah. I
mean, it's that's the story with the
internet too, right? It's like people
had this utopian idea where it was going
to be like an amazing thing for humanity
and it was going to be nothing but good
and egalitarian and beautiful and then
people started using the internet in a
really big way and you know hundreds and
then thousands of people started getting
online and actually interacting with
each other and it kind of turned crazy
quickly. Um so I think the same thing
happened with AI and with this
technology. Um someone found a way to
face swap really easily which is
something people were already doing. um
using AI and it just exploded from
there. I think the experts that I talked
to at the time said, "Oh, give it, you
know, this will be a a huge thing within
a few months and it was maybe 3 weeks
where people were making uh
non-consensual intimate images of
celebrities in mass. Uh it was a huge
thing and now I think we're seeing it
get more awareness I think because it's
happening in schools. Kids are dealing
with this now. And I think that's
something that um we're going to have to
kind of we're going to have to reckon
with legally and as a society and as far
as like internet regulations and things
like that, but also just I think there
needs to be some kind of introspection
about how we got here, why we why we let
it get this far. Um you know, who kind
of let it go to the point where, you
know, 13-year-olds are making porn of
their classmates using AI. I think
that's something that the adults in the
room need to sit down and introspect
about a little bit. Um, and I think
that's something that we're we try to do
when we write about um, this stuff in a
really early stage. It's like, let's
talk about it now. Um, let's kind of get
the lay of the land now and figure out
what's going on before it becomes so
commonplace that a 12-year-old is
getting arrested for it. You know,
that's it's such a um such an explosion
